Award.AwardTitle: UNS : Nanoplasmonic interferometric sensor array for dynamic multiplexed functional assay of white blood cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512417 Bartoli, Filbert J.

The researchers will fabricate a new sensor array that will analyze secretory function of immune cells at a single cell. It is believed by scientists that such understanding is important in understanding an important part of human physiology, the immune response. The impact of a successful complete of the project will be new data on how immune cells behave, and that could potentially be used in understanding diseases.


This research will develop a sensing platform that possesses the temporal and spatial resolution required for dynamic, multiplexed sensing of secretory function of immune cells at the single-cell level. Intellectual Merit: Nanoplasmonic interferometric sensor arrays will be designed and fabricateed at predefined locations in a microfluidic platform, with careful alignment of functionalized surfaces for multiplexed biomolecular detection and for dynamic multiplexed sensing of single cells. Nanoplasmonic interferometric sensors is expected to exhibit two orders of magnitude greater spatial resolution than currentmethods, and two orders of magnitude lower detection limit than nanohole array plasmonic sensors with comparable spatial resolution. The microfluidic biosensing platform will be integrated with the interferometric sensor arrays for monitoring the single cell dynamic secretion pattern of three cytokines (IL-10, MMP-9 and IFN-gamma) from sixteen LPS-stimulated macrophages. These data are useful in the understanding of the dynamics and heterogeneity of immune response. It will advance the fundamental understanding of immunological function, and potentially impact development of new diagnostics and therapeutics for infection, inflammation, and autoimmune disease. Broader Impacts: Integration of research and education is a high priority of the proposed research, which will provide opportunities for undergraduate and graduate student training, giving them access to new entirely instrumentation for interdisciplinary laboratory experiences. The research will contribute to new course development and directly impact the undergraduate curriculum. The investigators will actively participate in ongoing K-12 outreach programs focused on underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many biological applications require multiplexed sensors with both spatial and temporal resolutions comparable to single cell processes. Surface plasmon resonance based sensors are appealing for these applications given their label free nature, while conventional plasmonic sensors either have poor spatial resolution or limited detection resolution for biomolecular interactions. This grant supported the development of nanoplasmonic sensor arrays that have both a small footprint and low detection limits compatible with single cell analysis. We optimized the design and geometry of the sensor arrays for most sensitive performance in the cell culture medium. Functionalized with specific antibodies at pre-registered locations, the sensor arrays were shown to detect quantitatively two types of molecules, MMP9 and TIMP1, with a linear sensor response to the molecular concentration in the range relevant for cell secretion analysis. The sensors were then demonstrated to detect MMP9 secreted from lymphocytes after stimulation by an endotoxin. The results were consistent with biochemically determined values while offering the real-time sensor capability. Furthermore, the sensors were shown to detect MMP9 and TIMP1 in a multiplexed fashion, promising to monitor the dynamic interplay of molecules in the cell secretome.

The intellectual merit of the research includes pushing the frontiers of nanoplasmonics and biophotonics, and advancing lab-on-a-chip technology and biomedical engineering. It offers a powerful engineering tool for the fundamental understanding of immunological function, and for the development of new diagnostics and therapeutics for infection, inflammation, and autoimmune disease. To create a broader impact, the research team has presented the research findings at two professional conferences and published one peer-reviewed journal article. These findings have also been incorporated into the teaching materials and demonstrations to motivate undergraduate students to research and educate the public about STEM fields. One female electrical engineering student was supported by the grant and successfully obtained a Ph.D. degree to contribute the national work force.
